metadata.case_name: Bombay Gas Co. Ltd. v. Respondents (District Siphon Pumpers and Heat Appliances Repairers Inspectors)

facts.text: 16 respondents, employees of Bombay Gas Co. Ltd., District Siphon Pumpers and Heat Appliances Repairers Inspectors, filed applications under section 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 before Second Labour Court, Bombay in I.D.A. Nos. 447 to 462 of 1958.

Respondents claimed benefit from award in I.T. No. 54 of 1949 published May 11, 1950, directing: 'The demand in respect of the workers of the Mains, Services and District Fittings Departments and Lamp Repairers and others who were till 1948 required to work on Sundays and in respect of whom a weekly day off was enforced thereafter without any corresponding increase in wages is granted. In respect of the rest, the demand is rejected.'
Prior to 1946, most workers worked 7 days a week. By August 1946, weekly offs enforced for major section without wage adjustment based on 26 working days.
Demand No. 11(a): Workers should get paid weekly off; specifically for Mains, Services, District Fittings, Lamp Repairers affected by loss of overtime/Sunday work.
Labour Court framed 10 preliminary issues, rejected appellant's preliminary objections on June 3, 1961.
After evidence, Labour Court on September 29, 1961 directed appellant to pay specified amounts to respondents, computing from date earlier award enforceable till applications.
Respondents required to work on Sundays till 1948, though not always all Sundays; weekly off introduced without wage increase. Ext. 32 shows requirement to work Sundays before Sept 1948.
In 1952, demand made on behalf of respondents for similar benefit, refused by Bombay Govt as already considered.
Applications filed in 1958, about 8 years after 1950 award.

legal_issues.text: Whether applications under s.33C(2) maintainable and Labour Court had jurisdiction.
Whether claim barred by res judicata.
Whether direction in 1950 award given without jurisdiction by adding 'and others'.
Whether conditions precedent in direction satisfied by respondents.
Whether claim barred by laches/belatedness under s.33C(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Applications not maintainable under s.33C(2); barred by res judicata.
1950 award direction without jurisdiction as Tribunal exceeded terms of reference by adding 'and others' under demand 11(b).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(1)(d) Industrial Disputes Act; limited jurisdiction of Tribunals

petitioner_arguments.text: Direction does not cover respondents; they never claimed earlier, made 1952 demand.
Respondents not required to work all Sundays till 1948.
Claim belated (8 years); laches apply by analogy to Payment of Wages Act (1 year limit); Art.181 Limitation Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Payment of Wages Act s.22; Limitation Act Art.181

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to benefit under 1950 award direction as workers required to work Sundays till 1948, weekly off without wage increase.

court_reasoning.text: Applications competent under s.33C(2); Labour Court can interpret award, consider if nullity, analogous to execution proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Court in position of executing court.

court_reasoning.text: Direction relates to demand 11(a), not confined to 11(b); 'and others' justified for similar workers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies to all workers till 1948 required to work Sundays, weekly off without wage increase.

court_reasoning.text: Clause covers respondents; 1952 demand irrelevant to construction.
Test is whether workers could be required to work Sundays, not actually worked all; satisfied per Ext.32.
No limitation under s.33C(2); legislature omitted deliberately; not analogous to Payment of Wages Act; Art.181 inapplicable.

holdings.text: Labour Court has jurisdiction under s.33C(2) to compute benefits, interpret awards, refuse null awards.
1950 award direction valid, within jurisdiction, covers respondents, conditions satisfied.
No laches or limitation applies to s.33C(2) proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of s.33C(2) jurisdiction to compute benefits.
Art.181 Limitation Act applies only to CPC applications.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hansraj Gupta v. Official Liquidators, Dehra Dun Mussoorie Electric Tramway Co. Ltd.
Sha Mulchand Co. Ltd. v. Jawahar Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.181 limited to CPC despite amendments.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for applications to compute benefits; Tribunal jurisdiction limited to reference.

statutes_cited.name: Payment of Wages Act, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes 1 year limit for wage claims; analogy rejected for s.33C(2).

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.181 inapplicable to s.33C(2); no limitation imported.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by special leave, upholding Labour Court's preliminary order of June 3, 1961 and final order of September 29, 1961 directing payment of computed benefits to respondents from enforceability of 1950 award till applications.
outcome.relief_granted: Upheld direction to pay specified amounts to respondents.

key_quotes.text: "The proceedings contemplated by s.33C(2) are, in many cases, analogous to execution proceedings."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature of Labour Court jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "Where the legislature has made no provision for limitation, it would not be open to the courts to introduce any such limitation on grounds of fairness or justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The test is did the terms and conditions of service impose an obligation on the workers to attend duties on Sundays if called upon to do so?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets 'required to work on Sundays' in award.
